justification: “Perhaps most relevant to the present investigation is a measure of decision-making competence developed by Bruine de Bruin and colleagues… This individual-difference measure includes a set of seven behavioral tasks.”
The paper notes “individual differences in bias blind spot” and cites Scopelliti et al. (2015) who created a self–other comparison measure to quantify the construct.

“People vary in the extent to which they neglect external demands when inferring traits from others’ behaviors (Scopelliti et al., 2018).” – indicating a scale that captures those individual differences.

The manuscript defines receptiveness and references work by Hussein & Tormala (2021) and Minson, Chen, & Tinsley (2020) who “reveal that individuals higher in dispositional receptiveness are more likely to consume information from the opposite side,” implying the use of their receptiveness scale to measure the construct.
